title: Part A: Thesis
stimulusHtml:
A thesis is an arguable statement about a subject.

The thesis may appear anywhere within the essay.

A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully conveys that line of reasoning.

This is a partial task designed for students to practice drafting first responses to a timed analysis question. While the task is shortened for sake of practicing analysis, at this point in the course students should already be reasonably well acquainted with the understandings and skills related to analysis, including the necessary argument skills. As such, they should be able to compose clear, focused thesis statements in response to the prompt.
descriptions: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
Responds to the prompt with a defensible thesis that analyzes the writer’s rhetorical choices.

title: Part B: Evidence AND Commentary
stimulusHtml:
Commentary connects the evidence and reasoning to the thesis.

This prompt is the first progress check Rhetorical Analysis question encountered by students that asks them to develop an argument about the rhetorical choices made by the author. To encourage students to focus on the explanation of the relationships between textual evidence and their claims and to avoid penalizing students who aren’t yet as consistent as they should be by the end of the course, the rubric is such that students may only earn up to 3 points in this row for this question. In some cases, student responses may exceed the criteria for these 3 points on this formative assessment. Students will be able to earn up to 4 points in this row in later units and on the summative AP Exam.
descriptions: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
The response meets one of the following criteria:

The response meets both of the following criteria:

Makes textual references (direct quotes or paraphrases) that are relevant to the thesis.

AND

Provides commentary; however, it repeats, oversimplifies, or misinterprets the cited information or evidence.

The response meets both of the following criteria:

Makes textual references (direct quotes or paraphrases) that are relevant to the thesis.

AND

Provides commentary that explains the relationship between evidence and the thesis; however, commentary is uneven, limited, or incomplete.

title: Part C: Sophistication
stimulusHtml:
Demonstrates sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation by:

1. Situating the argument within a broader context, recognizing the implications of the argument.

2. Making effective rhetorical choices that strengthen the force and impact of the student’s argument.
Although this is a partial task, students may understand enough about the audience and context of an argument by this point in the course to be able to earn the point in this row. You might still consider awarding this point to even the less successful attempts at these forms of rhetorical sophistication so as to encourage students to experiment and take risks in their writing.
descriptions: Response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation.
Response demonstrates sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation.
